descendants.content:
@grootinside @breadandcircuses

See The Political Economy of Degrowth by Timothee Parrique
Part Iii receipes for degrowth (Post Growth)

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/339844751_The_Political_Economy_of_Degrowth

account.note:
Nature Marche Cuisine lecture  Carpe Diem & Insoumission.  « il faut allier le pessimisme de la raison à l’optimisme de la volonté » Gramsci  #nucleaire non merci
Théâtre amateur
Vit chez ses.chats

descendants.content:
@Gilins3 @grootinside @breadandcircuses

I like what I see here. . .
The only problem is electing ppl who will follow this course.

"However, degrowth recognizes the infeasibility of technological decoupling as well as the disastrous consequences that continuing to pursue economic growth entails. Instead, degrowth is guided by the precautionary principle; meaning that it is more prudent to aim for a degrowth transformation than to bet on future technologies (that do not yet exist) to alleviate climate change (Parrique, 2020). Most advocates of this approach also recognize that the pursuit of economic growth and the continuation of capitalism is not only an ecological problem but also a social one. ...
... Some common degrowth proposals include top-down policies such as: universal basic income; universal basic services (e.g. healthcare and education); job guarantee (government guarantees employment for all who want it); high taxes on wealth and luxury consumption; and putting a cap on key resources and sharing them in an equitable way (i.e., cap-and-share programmes) (Parrique, 2020). More bottom-up degrowth strategies include: local self-provisioning of food, energy and other basic necessities; sharing and swapping networks to better distribute existing goods; and neighbourhood 'maker spaces' where community members can access tools and knowledge to repair and refurbish existing products (Barlow et al., 2022). ...
... Overall, these principles resonate strongly with general degrowth conceptualizations (see e.g. Kallis, 2018;Parrique, 2020). Similarly, many of these principles are echoed in the alternative organization literature (see Parker et al., 2014)."

"... A review of the post-growth literature identifies several key characteristics of SJSs (see D'Alisa et al., 2014;Jackson, 2017;Raworth, 2017;Parrique, 2019;Kallis et al., 2020;Schmelzer et al., 2022, amongst others). They include i) the reconnection to ourselves, to each other, to our work, and to the non-human world; ii) the pursuit of sufficiency through redistribution rather than accumulation through growth 4 ; iii) an increased role for the commons, collectivism, localism, and meaningful social participation; iv) work as a meaningful activity centred on care and the satisfaction of human needs; v) the decommodification of society through production for use-value; and vi) a non-dualistic view of nature in which human society is not seen as independent of the rest of the living world. ...
... By providing an income floor, UBI is widely advocated within both the UBI and post-growth literature for its poverty reduction potential (Alexander, 2014a;Raworth, 2017;Parrique, 2019;Standing, 2020), which has been empirically demonstrated by numerous pilot interventions (Hasdell, 2020). UBI is also proposed as a vital tool for redistributing social wealth and resources. ...
... A major strand of scholarship on UBI argues that the policy would change our relationship to work. A key argument is that UBI would strengthen the bargaining position of employees and so improve working conditions (Widerquist, 2013;Parrique, 2019). Research from the Manitoba Basic Annual Income Experiment, which took place in Canada during the 1970 s, found evidence that, as an alternative source of income, the UBI tightened labour markets and pulled wages up (Calnitsky, 2018). ..."

descendants.content:
@jargoggles @breadandcircuses Agree! Some relatively simple ideas on this level - simple in that we already have tax codes in place and adjusting those policies to be more effective is relatively simple compared to other stuff:

- Taxing passenger vehicles by weight
- Increasing gas tax
- Increase taxes on luxury modes of travel, ie. yachts, private jets, RVs
- move property taxes to something like a land value tax (discourages SFH, large useless turf lawns, mansions, golf courses etc.)

descendants.content: @breadandcircuses and one would think this goes as far as how things are produced. Many products on the market use proprietary designs and intellectual property to limit control and manufacturing to ever increasingly large corporations. A sustainable future needs designs that are available for the common good and outside corporate control. These designs could then be used as a uniform base for product lines, reducing costs and waste, while also extending the life of those goods.
